Issues.Title: Bulma hero does not play well for tabs within a box.
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma CSS bug**.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Firefox 107.0
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

`tabs` within a `box` within a `hero-info` is not showing correctly. 


### Steps to Reproduce

Following is a CodePen to reproduce it: the top one is the default behaviour, the bottom one has some extra CSS.

https://codepen.io/AlexisTM/pen/abKEbXr

To overcome the issue, I added: 

```css
section.hero.is-info .tabs li.is-active a {
    color:#FFFFFF !important;
    background-color: #485fc7 !important;
}
```

The added section in front is to be prioritized against the following Bulma lines: (It was not `!important` at 0.7.4)

```css
.hero.is-info .tabs li.is-active a {
  color: #3e8ed0 !important;
  opacity: 1;
}
```

### Expected behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6976744/202858355-cc92a5fa-f617-41aa-9c70-fd9c4cb8772f.png)


### Actual behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6976744/202858339-5c006946-d852-48a4-8827-340b8a07f84f.png)

Issues.Title: Remove repetition of class name for native HTML elements
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

I'd like to understand the **rationale** behind class names having the same name as tag names. As much as I like the aesthetics portrayed by the CSS framework, it is unclear as to why one would not prefer using the framework to markup the style just by using the native HTML tags, e.g. have `<button>XYZ</button>` instead of `<button class="button">XYZ</button>`. Similar logic follows for `<progress>`, `<input>`, etc.

### Expected behavior

It'd be preferable to have the markup directly applied to `<button>`, `<input>`, etc. tags rather than using the same tag names as class names. The only place where class names should include tag names is where one is supposed to be represented in the form of the other.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove repetition of class name for native HTML elements" (#3589)

Issues.Title: has-navbar-fixed-* works only on html/body
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

The class `has-navbar-fixed-top`/`has-navbar-fixed-bottom` can only be applied to the `<html>` or `<body>` element ([see docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/components/navbar/#fixed-navbar)). This restriction is unnecessarily strong. In my case, I'm using React, can't easily access the toplevel HTML tree and would like to trigger this definition conditionally in my app (somewhere deeper in tree). Unfortunately, Bulma doesn't provide that in this way.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Chromium
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**.

### Expected behavior

If the [definition in navbar.sass](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/sass/components/navbar.sass#L129-L134) would be a bit more extensive, meaning the restriction with `<html>` or `<body` would be removed, I could use the Bulma class as intended.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "has-navbar-fixed-* works only on html/body" (#3583)

https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/1af081285ef37990ce4b25ed9b1166ff3397ab08/sass/components/navbar.sass#L239
https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/1af081285ef37990ce4b25ed9b1166ff3397ab08/sass/components/navbar.sass#L247-L249

The rule resulting from first block (`.navbar-link:not(.is-arrowless):after`) is more specific than second one (`.navbar-link:after`) which makes the second always superseded.

### Proposed solution
Add `:not(.is-arrowless)` specifier for mobile viewport

Issues.Title: Add an equivalent of Bootstrap's stretched links
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
It's a **feature request**.
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.4]
My **browser** is: Firefox 104.0.1
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

Currently, there's no class in Bulma that is a functional equivalent of [Bootstrap's stretched links](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.2/helpers/stretched-link/). In short, it's a class that, when applied to the `<a>` element, makes the entire containing block, such as cards, clickable as if it were part of the link. This not only improves code readability, but also makes the performed action more clear since it also highlights the `.stretched-link` element.

Currently, the closest alternative is to make the box an `<a>` element. While it does the job, it highlights the entire box, and putting any links inside it, like a button, breaks the whole thing.
